The sonic-sairedis change from https://github.com/sonic-net/sonic-sairedis/pull/1613 modified the behavior of BULK operations which resulted in the log spew looking different before and after on API failures. This impacts test_duplicate_route.py. As this test is failing with the above sonic-sairedis change included, sonic-buildimage PRs that bump up the submodule reference fail pipeline checks.

The fix is to update the regexes so that the test can continue to pass with and without this sonic-sairedis change.

Fixes # 20231

@echuawu - what is the motivation for the change? did something happened recently in sonic-mgmt causing deployment to take more time?

> @echuawu - what is the motivation for the change? did something happened recently in sonic-mgmt causing deployment to take more time?

There are not only one SSH sessions during anisble add-topo step, and if one of the SSH session execution time is longer than 120 s, it would lead to the other SSH sessions timeout. 
Recently, there were many changes in the add-topo steps, they may affect the original follows. But the 120 seconds timeout just happens from time to time.

Hi @lerry-lee , do we still need the `sleep 60`? This magic sleep does not make sense to me. We can remove the huge dummy file in the finally section in stead of waiting 60 seconds and delete in a background process. I would suggest to add the optimization i proposed in #19814 in your change

> Hi @lerry-lee , do we still need the `sleep 60`? This magic sleep does not make sense to me. We can remove the huge dummy file in the finally section in stead of waiting 60 seconds and delete in a background process. I would suggest to add the optimization i proposed in #19814 in your change

I get your point, I want to keep the original logic because it is safer to bundle the allocation of large files and deletion together and execute them on the device, even if the test process exits or the test script crashes in the middle. Because except for cleaning up in the final, we have no other place to clean it up, but if leaves large files behind, it may affect the health of the device and other test cases.

@Ndancejic Can you help me understand `During neighbor generation for the test, some of the neighbor updates were being missed from APPL_DB on sn4700 devices.` ? Is it possible that doing it in batch hides some real issue?

> @Ndancejic Can you help me understand `During neighbor generation for the test, some of the neighbor updates were being missed from APPL_DB on sn4700 devices.` ? Is it possible that doing it in batch hides some real issue?

I noticed that some of the neighbor entries being added at the start of the test were not being notified in appdb. appdb gets these from netlink when programming neighbors through the kernel. From what I understand if there's a high volume, these can be dropped from the kernel sometimes. In this case we were programming ~2000 entries in a single `ip neigh replace` command
